stages.name: Albert Park Grand Prix Circuit
stages.history: The Albert Park circuit is a street circuit located in Melbourne. Since 1996, it has hosted the Australian Grand Prix, being a temporary circuit that uses public roads around Albert Park Lake.

stages.name: Shanghai International Circuit
stages.history: Designed by Hermann Tilke and opened in 2004, the Shanghai circuit is known for its distinctive Chinese 'Shanghai' character shape and spectacular main grandstand. It has hosted the Chinese GP since its inauguration.

stages.name: Suzuka International Racing Course
stages.history: Suzuka is one of F1's most iconic circuits, opened in 1962. Owned by Honda, it's famous for its figure-8 layout, the 130R corner, and the 'Spoon' sequence. It has hosted the Japanese GP since 1987.

stages.name: Bahrain International Circuit
stages.history: Opened in 2004 as the first Middle Eastern circuit to host an F1 GP. Designed by Hermann Tilke, it's known for its multiple configurations and for being the setting of night races.

stages.name: Jeddah Corniche Circuit
stages.history: Street circuit opened in 2021, it's the fastest street track in F1. Located along the Red Sea in Jeddah, it features fast corners and little runoff, making it one of the most challenging layouts on the calendar.

stages.name: Miami International Autodrome
stages.history: Semi-street circuit opened in 2022 around the Hard Rock Stadium. It combines permanent sections with temporary streets and was designed to deliver a show with exclusive VIP areas and a party atmosphere.

stages.name: Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari
stages.history: Known as Imola, this historic circuit hosted the San Marino GP and since 2020 the Emilia Romagna GP. It was the scene of the tragic 1994 weekend when Ayrton Senna and Roland Ratzenberger lost their lives.

stages.name: Circuit of Monaco
stages.history: The world's most famous street circuit, held since 1929. With its narrow streets, tight corners and elevation changes, it's considered the ultimate driver's challenge and the most prestigious race to win.

stages.name: Circuit of Barcelona-Catalunya
stages.history: Opened in 1991 for the Barcelona Olympics, it's the circuit where teams conduct most preseason testing. Known for its final Nueva Honda corner that provides overtaking opportunities.

stages.name: Circuit Gilles Villeneuve
stages.history: Located on Notre-Dame Island in Montreal, this circuit is named after legendary Canadian driver Gilles Villeneuve. Known for its 'Wall of Champions' at the final corner that has 'caught' many famous drivers.

stages.name: Red Bull Ring
stages.history: Originally called Ã–sterreichring (1969-1995) and then A1-Ring, it was renovated by Red Bull and reopened in 2011. With its mountainous scenery and short length, it provides exciting racing with multiple overtaking opportunities.

stages.name: Silverstone Circuit
stages.history: Located on a former WWII airbase, Silverstone hosted the first F1 GP in 1950. With its fast corners like Copse, Maggotts and Becketts, it's considered the 'home' of British F1.

stages.name: Circuit of Spa-Francorchamps
stages.history: One of the oldest (1921) and most beloved circuits by drivers and fans. With its long Kemmel straight, Eau Rouge-Raidillon corners and changeable weather, Spa delivers spectacular racing.

stages.name: Hungaroring
stages.history: Opened in 1986 behind the Iron Curtain, it was the first F1 circuit in a communist country. With its narrow, twisty design, it's known as 'Monaco without walls' and usually provides strategic races.

stages.name: Circuit Zandvoort
stages.history: Opened in 1948, Zandvoort hosted the Dutch GP from 1952 to 1985 before its return in 2021. With its orange party atmosphere and spectacular banked final corner (Arie Luyendykbocht), it's a unique circuit.

stages.name: Autodromo Nazionale di Monza
stages.history: Known as 'The Temple of Speed', Monza is the fastest circuit on the calendar. Opened in 1922, it's famous for its parabolic corners and long F1 history, hosting the Italian GP since 1950.

stages.name: Baku City Circuit
stages.history: Street circuit opened in 2016 that combines narrow sections in the old city with a long straight along the Caspian Sea. Known for producing unpredictable races and multiple incidents.

stages.name: Marina Bay Street Circuit
stages.history: Opened in 2008 as F1's first night race, this street circuit is one of the most physically demanding due to humidity and 23 corners. Its spectacular views with Singapore's skyline make it unique.

stages.name: Circuit of The Americas
stages.history: Opened in 2012, COTA was specifically designed for F1 with influences from iconic corners like Spa's Eau Rouge and Hockenheim's Stadium. Its spectacular Turn 1 with steep elevation is one of its trademarks.

stages.name: AutÃ³dromo Hermanos RodrÃ­guez
stages.history: Named after the RodrÃ­guez brothers (Mexican drivers), this circuit hosted F1 between 1963-1970 and 1986-1992 before returning in 2015. Its spectacular stadium section (Foro Sol) and high altitude (2,285m) make it unique.

stages.name: AutÃ³dromo JosÃ© Carlos Pace
stages.history: Known as Interlagos, this circuit opened in 1940 is famous for its undulating terrain and challenging corners like 'S do Senna'. It has produced some of the most exciting races in F1 history.

stages.name: Las Vegas Strip Circuit
stages.history: Street circuit opened in 2023 that runs along the famous Las Vegas Strip past iconic casinos and hotels. With its nighttime spectacle and party atmosphere, it aims to become the most glamorous GP on the calendar.

stages.name: Losail International Circuit
stages.history: Opened in 2004 for motorcycle racing, it hosted its first F1 GP in 2021. With its desert layout and high-speed corners, it presents a physical challenge for drivers, especially in extreme heat conditions.

stages.name: Yas Marina Circuit
stages.history: Opened in 2009 as F1's first day/night race, this futuristic circuit on Yas Island is known for its 5-star hotel that spans the track (Yas Viceroy) and for traditionally being the season's final race.
